pros: I worked with Cancer Research UK for a few years in different roles, including shop volunteer, fundraiser, intern, and eventually a full-time employee in multiple head office roles. While some of these experiences were positive, my overall experience with the organisation was mixed. To begin with the positives, I met some lovely people during my time at Cancer Research UK, some of whom have become friends for life. As a shop volunteer, intern and fundraiser, I had the opportunity to work with a wide range of people who were passionate about supporting the charity's mission. However, my experience as a full-time employee in head office roles was quite different. I ultimately left after an experience where I felt I was bullied by my line manager, and felt I had no choice but to leave.
cons:
The corporate environment at Cancer Research UK was difficult to navigate, and the hierarchy was very pronounced. Senior staff members were often inaccessible, making it challenging to get things done efficiently. As a junior employee, I found it challenging to get any face-to-face time with these individuals, let alone have an informal chat. It felt like there was a clear hierarchy in place, and if you were below a certain level, you were simply not important enough to warrant their attention. 

Additionally, some of the processes in place were outdated and inefficient, which made it difficult to work effectively. One of the most significant challenges I faced during my time at Cancer Research UK was in my final role, where I felt I was bullied by a manager. I was excited to make an internal move into a more creative role. Unfortunately, I found that weeks into this position, the new manager's approach quickly escalated beyond normal performance expectations and became both strange and extreme.

Despite my very junior level and best efforts to perform well, I felt their focus on my mistakes was entirely disproportionate, and that she was actively looking for ways to set me up for failure. Additionally, she declined any requests to work from home and cast suspicion on the ‘true nature’ of my absence when I developed flu in the winter.

This constant scrutiny and criticism began to have a significant impact on my confidence, job satisfaction and mental health. I found myself constantly doubting my abilities and questioning my every move.

When I reported the bullying to HR, I was informed that my complaint was unlikely to be successful because I could not prove malicious intent. Years later, I realised this is not how employment law works, but I was very junior at the time. The charity offered me the option to abandon my grievance and leave with a month’s pay, which I felt I had no choice but to accept. 

This situation caused a great deal of stress and emotional turmoil, and it took me a year to fully recover my confidence. The individual continued to work at the charity and progressed to a more senior level, so I would never consider returning.

Overall, my experience with Cancer Research UK was mixed. While I met some wonderful people and had some positive experiences, the corporate environment was challenging for a junior employee. I was let down by HR's response to my bullying complaint, despite the charity's messaging about the importance of addressing bullying in the workplace (ironically).

HOW? Ask local business, if you could set up stall there, where people drop off their donations, or simply ask local business to donate  their unwanted stock. OUR INTERNET IS BLOCKED: we cannot use e-mail, so of course, during day, you have no time for this,  as you deal with donations, refunds, shop being tidy, training the volunteers, hiring volunteers, doing the H&S checks. When will you do it then? I tell you. At home, in your own time, but you get paid only for about 36 hours work weekly. In fact we do rarely have lunch breakes. Plus we need to overlook the H&S. pros: Cancer Research UK is run like a FTSE 100 and has the benefit of being full of highly motivated and great people. pros: Most people I work *with* are hardworking, intelligent individuals. They are experts in their field, have a good working knowledge and lots of ideas. They also have a passion for the cause and want the charity to succeed, very little selfishness.

Unfortunately the senior management is a different story, they only want themselves to succeed, it really is like an old boys club where everybody has each other’s backs and they do not care how they treat people – neither their employees or even external suppliers.

* There are too many cliques, and most of them in senior management, they operate largely on gossip which I feel is very unprofessional
* Opportunities are given to people based on popularity and not successes.  You maybe have driven several projects to a very successful end but if management feel you are not towing the party line then that counts for nothing. 
* Which needs me to feedback, you are encouraged to give feedback but then you are punished for it (hence why I will be posting this anonymously).  Even if you give your feedback in a structured way and via the correct route, after it was requested - if it is anyway disagreeable to them then you have a black mark against your name… now I said in the pros that my colleagues want the charity to succeed, and so it’s all the more frustrating when your feedback is dismissed in this way because you feel the charity itself is being let down by these bigots.
* There is way too much bureaucracy, making it difficult for everything to run efficiently… CR-UK has become a slow and cumbersome machine.  Recent changes have introduced yet more bureaucracy and it’s becoming increasingly difficult to meet targets.
* Nobody is made to feel truly valued, there are these overblown gestures that exist such as giving out childish awards or encouraging people to write silly thank you notes to their colleagues, which is really all about showmanship and has no sincerity in it whatsoever… yes they’re good at that.  But when you want some proper recognition, where it truly matters, then it’s not forthcoming.
* If you are an honest person, with integrity, who wishes for the charity to be the best it can be… then you are not going to succeed here, they will chew you up and spit you out.  But, if you are willing to play their games, if you self-promote rather than work hard, if you care more about perception than getting your hands dirty, then you may do well… I say ‘may’ because I am the former, I’m too honest, I have too much integrity, and in all truth I do not know what it takes to get on here, it’s just my guess.
